title: 15 Proven Ways to Get Listings as a Real Estate Agent (& Keep Them Coming)
excerpt: Key Points Listings bring leverage - buyers bring burnout. Focus on where the control is. Use cash offer programs to start seller conversations fast. Ditch…
content:
Key Points

  • Listings bring leverage – buyers bring burnout. Focus on where the control is.
  • Use cash offer programs to start seller conversations fast.
  • Ditch Zestimates. Offer detailed home valuations with real market insight.
  • FSBOs and expireds aren’t cold leads – they’re unfinished business.
  • Farming still works – when you show up like a brand, not a billboard.
  • Client referrals don’t happen unless you give them a reason to refer you.
  • Divorce attorneys, local events, and small businesses = secret seller pipelines.
  • Social media done right is a modern-day listing machine.

If you’ve ever cried in your car after another buyer ghosted you post-showing, welcome. This one’s for you.

Because no matter how many times the industry changes or the NAR rewrites the rules, one thing hasn’t changed: listings = leverage. Listing agents still get more control, less chaos, and let’s be real, less time chasing texts that start with “we’ve decided to wait.”

Yes, being a listing agent costs more upfront – photos, marketing, staging – but you’re also not spending your weekends unlocking doors for people whose “budget” is a Pinterest board and a dream. With the shift in buyer agent compensation (thanks NAR!), more buyers than ever are skipping agents altogether, but sellers? Sellers still need you. Badly. Especially if they want to avoid turning their property into a Zillow punchline.

So let’s get serious about how to get listings as a real estate agent, even if you’re new, rebuilding, or just tired of crossing your fingers at open houses. Here’s your handy-dandy index:

Table of Contents

Understand the Market First
Proven Strategies to Secure Listings (That Don’t Involve Begging Your Aunt’s Hairdresser for a Referral)
1. Offer Cash Deals That Flip the Script
2. Offer a Real Home Valuation (Not a Sad Zestimate Clone)
3. Turn Open Houses into Listing Traps (The Good Kind)
4. Rescue Expired Listings with Empathy (and a Game Plan)
5. Target FSBOs (a.k.a. For Sale But Still Very Unsold)
6. Implement Geographic Farming (No, Not the Corn Kind)
7. Turn Happy Clients into Walking, Talking Billboards
8. Partner with Divorce Attorneys (The Quiet Goldmine)
9. Host Seller Workshops That Don’t Feel Like Timeshares
10. Work Your Sphere Like a Pro (Not Like a Desperate Cousin)
11. Show Up at Local Events (and Talk Like a Human)
12. Partner with Local Businesses (Because Visibility = Trust)
13. Run Smart Ads That Speak to Sellers
14. Tap Into Pre-Foreclosure Leads (the Right Way)
15. Leverage Social Media (Without Turning Into a Cringe Reels Influencer)
You Don’t Need Luck – You Need Leverage
Smart Agent Alliance: Where Your Listings (and Revenue) Get a Boost
Frequently Asked Questions

Understand the Market First

If you’re serious about figuring out how to get listings as a real estate agent, you need more than a surface-level market update. Sellers don’t want a weather report – they want you to tell them whether it’s raining inside their zip code. So before you even think about sending another “Just Listed” postcard, do the homework.

Start with the Big Picture (a.k.a. Why Your Sellers Are Freaked Out)

You need to know what the national and regional housing trends are doing so you can sound like a pro – not someone who Googled “housing update” five minutes before a listing appointment.

Interest rates. Inflation. Inventory shifts. These aren’t just headlines – they’re the reason your seller’s neighbor’s house sat for 93 days or why bidding wars went MIA in your town. Show your clients how the macro trends trickle down into their backyard. Literally.

Demographic changes also matter. Are retirees moving in? Are millennials cashing out of downtown shoeboxes for suburban space? Understanding who’s coming and going helps you identify which homes are likely to list next – and what kinds of features will actually sell.

Then Zoom in Like You’ve Got a Microscope on Their Block

This is where you dominate – if you do it right. If you want to be the agent who lands more real estate listings, this is where you ditch the cookie-cutter comps pitch and show them what really sells.

Here’s what you need to do (no, really):

  • Walk every comparable like a detective, because photos won’t tell you if the layout feels awkward, if the house smells like wet carpet and regret, if the neighbor’s dog has a barking problem, or if the traffic noise sounds like a freeway in the foyer. Use that information when you:
  • Pull recent sales in the neighborhood and break them down by feature. Are homes with pools moving faster than homes with two-car garages? Is a remodeled kitchen getting offers in three days while grandma’s house with shag carpet sits for three months?
  • Look at days on market, sale-to-list ratio, and price-per-square-foot trends. What’s the tipping point for price? What’s the bare minimum upgrade that gets attention?
  • Analyze what actually makes the “sold” column – was it the open floor plan, the quartz countertops, or just the fact that it wasn’t painted beige?

Now take those insights and build a real estate listing presentation that doesn’t just show comps – it translates them into action steps for your sellers. Use Canva to spruce it up.

Tell them:

  • Whether they need to splurge on hardwoods or if fresh carpet will pass the sniff test – literally and figuratively.
  • Whether buyers in their zip code care about curb appeal or just want a good home office.
  • If their 90s bathroom is “vintage charm” or a deal killer in disguise.

And be clear about how you’re going to help them prep. Are you partnering with a company like Curbio or Freemodel to front the reno costs? Will you book the contractor, oversee the install, and babysit the painter? Let them know you’re not just throwing advice at them – you’re managing the whole listing prep like a project boss.

When you walk in with hyper-local insights and a clear listing checklist for getting the house market-ready, you’re not pitching. You’re proving. And that’s exactly how you get listings.

Proven Strategies to Secure Listings (That Don’t Involve Begging Your Aunt’s Hairdresser for a Referral)

Let’s be real: if how to get listings as a real estate agent were as easy as mailing one postcard or boosting a Facebook post, every agent would be buried in listings and sipping LaCroix on their Tuesday afternoon “CEO hour.”

But here’s the truth – real estate listings don’t fall from the sky. You earn them by being visible, credible, and freakishly consistent. Especially in a market where homeowners are bombarded by “I have a buyer for your home” flyers from agents who couldn’t find their own name on the MLS.

So whether you’re brand new and wondering how to get listings as a new real estate agent, or a seasoned pro looking to reboot, these listing strategies are designed to work now – not five years ago when inventory was falling out of the sky.

1. Offer Cash Deals That Flip the Script

Want a shortcut to seller conversations that don’t start with “I’m just curious”? Offer them something no Zestimate ever will: an actual offer.

Cash offer programs (like the ones available through eXp Realty) are gold for sparking interest – and here’s the twist: most sellers don’t take the cash. They take the listing. But that conversation wouldn’t happen without the hook.

  • Mention it in your mailers, ads, and open house flyers.
  • Use it to stand out from other agents who are still pitching “free home evaluations” like it’s 2009.
  • Let sellers know they have options – instant cash or a smarter listing strategy.

It’s a modern strategy for agents who want more real estate listings without begging.

2. Offer a Real Home Valuation (Not a Sad Zestimate Clone)

Everyone and their algorithm offers a home value. But when you show up with a 30-page custom CMA, neighborhood data, buyer trend insights, and a breakdown of ROI upgrades? Now you’re the expert – not the spammy postcard.

This strategy works whether you’re going after expireds, farming, or just trying to get a foot in the door.

  • Promote your free in-depth home valuation across social, your farm, and landing pages.
  • Make a clean QR code that drives people to a simple form (bonus points if it feeds straight into your CRM drip).
  • Use visuals, charts, and real data. Show them their online home value is a guess. Your data is the strategy.

Want more listings? Offer more value than the robots.

3. Turn Open Houses into Listing Traps (The Good Kind)

Most agents treat open houses like a passive hope-fest. You? You’re about to turn them into lead machines.

Before the first looky-loo walks in, hit the pavement:

  • Door knock the neighborhood with a one-page flyer: the home, the recent comps, and your QR code to join your market update email list or request a home valuation.
  • Mention you’re the listing agent in the area, and you’re actively connecting with homeowners about upcoming inventory needs.
  • Ask if they know anyone else thinking of selling – you’ll be surprised who spills the tea.

Spoiler: you’re not just holding an open house – you’re interviewing the block.

4. Rescue Expired Listings with Empathy (and a Game Plan)

Expired listings are the heartbreak kids of the MLS. Someone already wanted to sell – they just didn’t have the right agent (you know, like you).

So what do you do? You listen. Really listen.

  • Come back with a better plan: pro marketing, a pricing refresh, an upgrade strategy, and an actual communication promise.
  • Start with a letter, call, or door knock – then shut up and let them vent.
  • Ask what went wrong. The agent? The pricing? The photos? The lack of follow-up? They’ll tell you – loudly.

If you want to know how to get expired listings in 2025, it starts with empathy, not ego.

5. Target FSBOs (a.k.a. For Sale But Still Very Unsold)

For Sale By Owner listings are like DIY haircuts – usually well-intentioned, sometimes passable, and often in need of professional help by week three.

FSBOs already made one key decision: they want to sell. That’s half the battle. They just don’t yet believe they need you… until their inbox fills with lowballs, scammers, and people asking if “rent-to-own” is an option.

This is where you step in – not with pressure, but with clarity and actual value.

  • Build a FSBO-specific marketing kit with before/after listing photos, staging tips, pricing strategy breakdowns, testimonials, and a sample real estate listing presentation template.
  • Offer easy-entry resources like a detailed CMA, home-selling checklist, or a newsletter that gives them real, actionable steps – without strings attached.
  • Focus on what keeps them up at night: safety, time, liability, and paperwork nightmares. Let them know you’ve got it handled.

Follow up like a human. Consistently – but never pushy. Keep adding value. That way, when they’re finally ready to stop playing listing agent, you’re the first one they call.

6. Implement Geographic Farming (No, Not the Corn Kind)

Want to know how to get more listings in real estate without chasing random leads all over town? Pick a patch and dig in. Hard.

Geographic farming still works – if you do it like a marketer, not a mailman.

  • Choose your farm based on turnover rate, neighborhood growth, and your own market familiarity. This is about smart strategy, not just convenience.
  • Mailers should give real value – like recent real estate listings that sold nearby, equity updates, or seasonal prep tips.
  • Be present offline too: block parties, PTA meetings, school functions. Show up, be helpful, don’t be weird.
  • Double up by hosting open houses for other listings in your farm and door-knocking the block with market data and that same irresistible home valuation offer.

Track everything – mailers, events, ads. You’re not farming for likes; you’re farming for listings. And yes, it takes repetition. Think 11+ touches minimum before someone even thinks about calling you. Stay visible. Stay valuable. Stay consistent.

7. Turn Happy Clients into Walking, Talking Billboards

The cheapest way to get more real estate listings? Stop letting your past clients vanish like they’re in witness protection.

Happy clients are more than just a nice testimonial. They’re your silent sales force – if you give them something to talk about.

  • After closing, deliver a thank-you card with a subtle referral line like, “Now accepting amazing humans you know who need to sell.”
  • Don’t push right away, but circle back later with your latest promo – “If you know someone looking to sell, I’m currently covering seller’s insurance” or whatever you’re offering this month.
  • Schedule an annual equity checkup with a fresh CMA and home update report. Remind them of their home’s value and your value at the same time.
  • Celebrate their home-iversary. Drop by with a coffee or mail a card. Make it personal, not pitchy.

The key? Stay top of mind without being annoying. You’re not a pop-up ad. You’re the helpful friend who always knows what homes are worth.

8. Partner with Divorce Attorneys (The Quiet Goldmine)

If you want to get strategic about how to get listings as a real estate agent, look for professionals who know when someone’s about to sell – before anyone else does.

Enter: divorce attorneys.

  • Start by building connections with local family and estate attorneys. Go to their networking events. Offer coffee, not contracts.
  • Create a seller guide for divorce situations, or co-host a seminar with a legal pro who can walk through timelines and division strategies.
  • Drop off sleek, non-cringey brochures at law offices that outline how you help sellers navigate tense transitions with empathy and results.

This is long game work – but the listings? They’re real, they’re often time-sensitive, and they need a listing agent who knows how to get things done without drama.

9. Host Seller Workshops That Don’t Feel Like Timeshares

Workshops and seminars are the ultimate credibility builder. You get to show off your expertise, earn trust face-to-face, and connect with would-be sellers who haven’t yet raised their hands.

But the key is making it about them, not a weird sales pitch.

  • Teach practical stuff: how to prep a home for sale, how to price smart in today’s market, what buyers actually want right now.
  • Share your listing checklist for getting top dollar – and break down which repairs/upgrades are worth doing.
  • Partner with contractors, stagers, or lenders who can offer value too (just make sure they don’t hijack your spotlight).
  • Capture emails with a sign-in sheet – or better yet, a tablet that feeds right into your CRM and starts an automated drip campaign. (Yes, BoldTrail can do this.)

Workshops not only give sellers clarity – they give you contact info, follow-up permission, and expert status. Total win.

10. Work Your Sphere Like a Pro (Not Like a Desperate Cousin)

Here’s a wild fact: most agents are sitting on a goldmine and don’t even realize it. If someone owns a home, they’re a future seller. Maybe not today – but someday. And if they already know you, that’s half the battle.

You don’t need to be salesy. You just need to be visible, valuable, and slightly less forgettable than their last agent who vanished after closing day.

  • Send handwritten notes, birthday cards, or just a “thinking of you” text that doesn’t start with “just checking in…”
  • Share real value: neighborhood sales updates, home equity estimates, and market trend emails that don’t make people’s eyes glaze over.
  • Host low-key client events like happy hours, backyard BBQs, or coffee shop pop-ins.
  • Schedule a quick “home equity check-in” every year – show them how much they’ve gained and offer a personalized CMA.

This is how you stay top of mind without being that agent. You’re not just building trust – you’re building a listing pipeline that doesn’t rely on strangers or cold calls.

11. Show Up at Local Events (and Talk Like a Human)

Want to know how to get listings as a new real estate agent? Step one: leave the house.

Local events – yes, even the ones with questionable lemonade and school choirs – are where real conversations happen. Because sellers aren’t looking for an agent when they’re ready… they’re looking for one they already know when the time comes.

  • Set up a booth at fairs, festivals, or community yard sales. Offer something simple: a home valuation QR code, a “what’s your home worth?” flyer, or just free bottled water.
  • Volunteer for local causes. Show you care about more than closing deals.
  • Go to events even when you’re not promoting. Chat. Be seen. Be helpful.
  • Collect contact info (nicely). Offer to add them to your monthly newsletter full of local tips, home equity insights, and fun facts – not just boring listings.

Real estate is still a relationship business. So put on your shoes, bring your smile, and maybe a few listing presentations in your trunk – just in case.

12. Partner with Local Businesses (Because Visibility = Trust)

Still wondering how to get more listings in real estate without blowing your budget? Collaborate instead of advertise.

Local businesses are also trying to build trust, get foot traffic, and look like community rockstars. That makes them ideal co-marketing partners.

  • Team up with coffee shops, gyms, bakeries, or salons for giveaways, cross-promotions, or email swaps.
  • Feature one local business in each edition of your seller newsletter or social media series – then ask them to return the favor.
  • Co-host community events like home-selling workshops, market trend nights, or pop-up consult booths during local art walks.

Bonus: These businesses often know before you do who’s thinking about selling. Why? Because sellers vent about their life changes everywhere. Be the agent every business wants to refer.

13. Run Smart Ads That Speak to Sellers

Paid ads don’t have to feel like throwing money into the algorithm void. When done right, online advertising is one of the fastest ways to land real estate listings – especially if you use the right hook.

  • Focus your offer around real value: a no-obligation cash offer, a free 30-page CMA, or a “What’s My Home Worth?” equity report.
  • Run ads on platforms where your potential sellers actually hang out: Facebook, Instagram, Nextdoor, Google, and even LinkedIn.
  • Target by zip code, home value, age, and life stage. A 62-year-old in a 4-bed suburban home? Yeah, they might be open to downsizing.
  • Use video tours, carousel ads, or short punchy clips to grab attention fast.

Track performance weekly. Double down on what’s working. Kill what’s not. You’re not just spending ad dollars – you’re buying attention, seller conversations, and future commissions.

14. Tap Into Pre-Foreclosure Leads (the Right Way)

No, it’s not slimy. Done well, helping people in pre-foreclosure is one of the most ethical and impactful ways to build your business and help your community.

These homeowners are under stress. But they also need options – and most of them have no idea what those options are. Be the person who shows up with empathy and answers.

  • Use tools like PropertyRadar or or follow DistressedPro’s four-step guide to secure foreclosure listings directly from banks.”
  • Offer real solutions: short sales, fast cash offers, or a traditional listing with a timeline they can manage.
  • Build relationships with foreclosure attorneys or financial counselors who can refer clients that are overwhelmed.
  • Provide printed guides or a custom listing checklist for sellers in distress.

Show up not to pitch, but to help. Do that, and you won’t just earn listings – you’ll earn a reputation for being the agent who actually cares.

15. Leverage Social Media (Without Turning Into a Cringe Reels Influencer)

Social media doesn’t need to be a parade of pointing, lip syncing, or dancing (unless that’s your vibe – no judgment). What it does need is relevance, consistency, and a little humanity.

If you’re wondering how do you get listings as a real estate agent in today’s digital world – start here.

  • Post weekly updates about the local market, like “3 homes sold in XYZ neighborhood last week under 7 days.”
  • Share before and after staging photos, sold stats, or a behind-the-scenes look at your listing presentation prep.
  • Get in on neighborhood Facebook groups, local Reddit threads, and Nextdoor conversations.
  • Ask for engagement: “Curious what your home is worth now?” or “Want to see what your neighbor’s home just sold for?”

Stay real, helpful, and just the right amount of visible. Social media isn’t magic. It’s just a modern version of door-knocking – with way better reach.

You Don’t Need Luck – You Need Leverage

There you have it: 15 no-fluff strategies for how to get listings as a real estate agent. Whether you’re chasing expireds, building a referral engine, or running smart ads, the truth is this: listings go to the agents who show up, follow up, and back it all with real strategy. For more great ideas to up your game, be sure to check out our Agent Success Hub and other ideas to get clients.

And here’s the part most agents miss – you don’t have to do this alone.

At eXp Realty, and especially with sponsor Smart Agent Alliance, you get powerhouse FREE sponsor team that actually helps you implement this stuff – so you don’t spend another month reinventing the wheel or staring at your CRM like it owes you a favor.

Smart Agent Alliance: Where Your Listings (and Revenue) Get a Boost

Most agents join eXp for the training or tech – but the ones who thrive? They figure out how to tap into eXp’s revenue share model. That’s where Smart Agent Alliance comes in. We’ll help you attract agents, grow passive income, and build a business that pays you long after the deal closes.  Curious what you could earn in passive income?
Play with the revenue share calculator here.

We also provide:

  • An onboarding team that gets you launched fast
  • A private portal with everything in one place
  • 8+ customizable lead capture pages and 100s of real estate templates

And, with SAA, you get two FREE value-packed sponsor teams because we’re part of the Wolf Pack, one of the highest-producing teams at eXp, with access to:

  • Elite coaching like Mike Sherrard’s Social Agent Academy Pro
  • Live mastermind calls and marketing breakdowns every week
  • Women-led masterminds and collaborative culture (not a hype group – we actually help each other)

Why try to do this solo when there’s a team already doing the heavy lifting – for you?

Learn more about eXp Realty and  Smart Agent Alliance today. Your future self will thank you.

Frequently Asked Questions

How do you get listings as a real estate agent?

You get listings by building trust, showing market expertise, and following up consistently. Use strategies like home valuations, expired listing outreach, geographic farming, and referral systems.

How do new real estate agents get listings?

New agents can get listings by leveraging their sphere of influence, offering free value (like a CMA), and focusing on areas with high turnover. Visibility + consistency = traction.

What is the fastest way to get more listings in real estate?

The fastest way is to offer cash deals or in-depth CMAs to spark conversations. Focus on sellers who’ve already shown interest – like FSBOs, expireds, or pre-foreclosures.

What is a listing presentation in real estate?

A listing presentation is your pitch to a homeowner about why they should hire you. It should include market data, pricing strategy, staging help, and your full marketing plan.

Is it better to work with buyers or sellers in real estate?

Most top agents prefer working with sellers. Listings offer more control, better leverage, and generate inbound buyer leads – helping you scale faster with less chaos.

title: The Best Real Estate Brokerage for New Agents in 2025
excerpt: Key Points The best brokerage for new agents depends on training, support, and structure. Not all “big names” deliver - local office quality varies wildly.…
content:
Key Points

  • The best brokerage for new agents depends on training, support, and structure.
  • Not all “big names” deliver – local office quality varies wildly.
  • Cloud-based models like eXp Realty offer daily training and sponsor teams.
  • New agents can work solo, on teams, or with sponsor support (or all three).
  • Sponsor teams help without taking your split, unlike production teams.
  • Beware of fees – franchise, tech, and desk charges can eat your income.
  • Top success factors: training, mentorship, culture, tech, leads, and growth.
  • Look for structured mentorship, not “you’ll figure it out eventually.”
  • Your first year should be about support, not survival mode.

New agents don’t fail because they don’t want it bad enough. They fail because no one told them how much “figure it out” would be part of the job description. Between the fees, the “training” that’s just a PDF graveyard, and sponsors who vanish like your high school crush, it’s no wonder most agents tap out early.

So if you’re a new real estate agent trying to dodge the crash-and-burn phase, here’s your north star: pick the brokerage that actually helps you close deals – not just the one with the loudest TikTok dance.

Your success isn’t just about which brokerage you choose – it’s about how that brokerage sets you up to win. Training, tools, support, leads, and culture all matter. Here’s your handy-dandy index:

Table of Contents

What is a Real Estate Broker (and Brokerage)?
Comparing Brokerage Models
Cloud-Based Brokerages
Traditional Franchise Brokerages
Local Independent Boutiques
Discount or Flat-Fee Models
Agent Roles: Solo, Team, or Sponsor Support
Solo Agent
Member of a Production Team
Solo Agent with a Sponsor
Member of a Sponsor Team
Commission Splits & Fees
Key Factors for New Agent Success
Choose the Brokerage That Sets You Up to Win
Frequently Asked Questions

What is a Real Estate Broker (and Brokerage)?

Let’s clear up the identity crisis. In real estate, the words broker and brokerage get tossed around like interchangeable salad toppings – but they’re not the same thing. And when you’re trying to figure out the best real estate brokerage for new agents, knowing the difference actually matters. A lot.

A real estate broker is a licensed pro who’s done the extra credit – more education, a tougher exam – and now has the legal authority to supervise agents or run their own show. They’re the ones who keep deals legal, contracts clean, and agents (mostly) out of trouble. Think of a broker as the designated driver of your real estate transactions.

A real estate brokerage, on the other hand, is a company under which brokers and agents work. The brokerage holds your license and provides your support structure, transaction systems, marketing tools, legal compliance, and—hopefully—some level of actual help.

So, why does this matter to you as a new agent?

Because picking the best real estate broker for new agents isn’t about the logo – it’s about the system behind it. A strong real estate brokerage gives you the training, tools, and support to survive those “what am I doing?” moments. One well-meaning broker can only help so much. The best brokerages offer real structure, real estate training for new agents, and resources that don’t vanish after your first week.

Comparing Brokerage Models

The best real estate brokerage for new agents isn’t one-size-fits-all. Different models come with different perks – and different landmines. Some offer full real estate coaching for new agents; others toss you a login and disappear. Here’s the short version of what you need to know:

Cloud-Based Brokerages

Think eXp Realty – no offices (but access to offices), no commute, just virtual training, strong tech, support from anywhere, and a whole lot of agent autonomy. It’s built for self-starters who want flexibility and efficiency. Wondering if eXp is good for new agents? Yep. eXp offers daily live training, onboarding, and sponsor teams to help with production, passive income, and community.

Traditional Franchise Brokerages

Big brands like RE/MAX and Keller Williams offer name recognition and in-person offices, but every location runs independently. One office might have stellar real estate training for new agents, another has zippo.

Expect lower commission splits (often 70/30 or worse), plus desk and franchise fees that chip away at your income. Ask detailed questions upfront – because you’re paying more, and what you get varies wildly. And, yes, online research about traditional brokerages is nearly impossible. Go to Glassdoor.com for some agent reviews.

Local Independent Boutiques

Usually run by a single broker, these offices might offer personalized mentorship, higher splits, and more autonomy than a franchise model. But training and tech depend entirely on the owner. If you like local vibes and direct access to leadership, this might be a fit. Just know that fewer staff means less support – and more is on you to figure out.

Discount or Flat-Fee Models

Low-cost, high-split models sound great – until you need help. These brokerages charge per transaction or monthly, but usually offer minimal training or tech. Best for experienced agents, not those learning how to convert leads or write clean contracts.

Agent Roles: Solo, Team, or Sponsor Support

Once you’ve picked the best real estate brokerage for new agents, you still need to figure out how you’ll actually work inside that brokerage. You’ve got a few role options – and each one comes with its own mix of support, splits, and day-to-day reality.

Let’s break down your three main paths: going solo, joining a team, or leveraging sponsor support.

Solo Agent

Most agents start out as solo agents. That means you’re running your own show under your brokerage’s umbrella. You pay the fees, generate the leads, and figure out your systems. You’re basically a one-person business with a real estate license and a dream.

This setup works best if your real estate brokerage for new agents actually offers strong onboarding, tech, and training. Otherwise, “solo” turns into “struggling in silence” – which is exactly why so many new agents tap out in year one. Some push through until the overwhelm hits, then pivot to a production team for support.

Member of a Production Team

Production teams are usually the first thing new agents hear about because they’re common inside most brokerages. These teams operate like mini-businesses designed to help agents buy and sell homes more efficiently. They typically provide leads, hands-on training, accountability, and a built-in sense of community. For many new agents, joining a team can be a fast-track to building confidence and closing deals—without having to reinvent the wheel on day one.

But here’s the catch: not all teams are created equal. Just like with franchise offices and independent boutique brokerages, some teams offer legit training and support – others hand you a script and wish you luck.

Also, teams come with their own split on top of your brokerage split. So while the leads and mentorship might flow, your paycheck will shrink accordingly. Before joining, ask questions about what you can expect and ask to see the team agreement – including how to exit. Some teams make it easy to leave. Others? Not so much.

Solo Agent with a Sponsor

This one’s unique to brokerages with a revenue share model, like eXp Realty. When you join, you name a sponsor – someone who benefits financially when you succeed. So in theory, they’re motivated to support you. In practice? Some do, some don’t. Everyone has time limits, so don’t count on endless hand-holding, especially from a solo sponsor.

The smart move? Choose a sponsor who offers actual value – like real estate coaching for new agents, marketing systems, or community – not just someone who slid into your DMs with “Let’s win together!” vibes.

Member of a Sponsor Team

Sponsor teams are also specific to brokerages with a revenue share model. These aren’t production teams – they don’t hold your hand through deals and most don’t take a split of your commissions. Instead, they provide tools, systems, and community designed to help you succeed as a solo agent. Think of it as an added layer of support – usually without an added layer of cost.

The catch? At brokerages like eXp Realty, you have to choose your sponsor team when you join eXp. After that, you’re locked in – unless you leave the company for a full year and come back. So yeah, doing your homework isn’t optional. On the upside, online research about eXp sponsors will help you decide.

Pick a sponsor team that’s organized, offers real tools and systems, and actually supports your production and revenue share goals. A strong community? That’s the frosting on your commission cake – and yeah, it matters!

Bonus: At eXp (and most other brokerages), sponsor team members can join a production team anytime. So if you start solo and realize you need a bit more structure (read: someone to boss you around in a helpful way), you can always become a production team member too. Just follow the advice above to make sure you’re picking the right team, not just the loudest one.

Commission Splits & Fees

We’ll keep this quick – our other blogs go deep on commission math, hidden fees, and how to not feel broke after your first closing. This section is just the essentials.

Commission splits are how your commission gets divided between you and your brokerage. The first number is your cut. So, if you’re on a 60/40 split, you keep 60%, and your brokerage takes 40%. Some brokerages use fixed splits, others use sliding scales that improve as you produce more. A few brokerages offer a cap – once you’ve paid in a set amount (like eXp’s $16K), you keep 100% for the rest of the year.

The tradeoff? Lower splits sometimes come with more support – like leads, training, and tech. Higher splits usually mean you’re more independent (read: figuring things out solo).

Now let’s talk fees – tech fees, desk fees, franchise fees, transaction fees. Some brokerages charge monthly. Others take a cut per deal. It all adds up fast, especially when you’re still ramping up. You can compare these for yourself using our brokerage comparison tool.

In any event, before you commit to a brokerage, ask for a detailed fee sheet: upfront, monthly, and per-transaction. Then check out our blogs on commission splits and fees so you know what you’re really taking home.

Key Factors for New Agent Success

Now that you’ve got a grip on brokerage types, splits, and fees, it’s time to talk about what really drives your success in this business. Because let’s be real – the best real estate brokerage for new agents isn’t the one with the flashiest office or the prettiest signs. It’s the one that actually sets you up to close deals, stay sane, and make it past year one.

A good fit means more than a name you recognize. It means real estate training for new agents that doesn’t suck, support when you hit a wall, and tools that actually help – not just look good in a sales pitch. These are the six key factors that separate thriving agents from the ones quietly ghosting their license renewal notices.

1. Training & Onboarding

Getting licensed teaches you how not to break the law. But getting trained teaches you how to actually sell houses.

Great brokerages start with a clear onboarding process (for example, here’s eXp’s) and continue with real estate coaching for new agents that includes contracts, negotiations, scripts, and even how to survive your first open house without crying in the bathroom. In competitive markets that includes local rules, city-specific disclosures, and hands-on practice – not just theory.

Look for brokerages that go beyond “read this PDF.” Weekly live sessions, role-playing, deal debriefs, shadowing top producers – that’s where the growth happens. And if they throw in a video library for after-hours studying? Bonus points.

2. Mentorship That’s Actually Useful

A true mentor doesn’t just sit near you and hope you learn by osmosis. The best real estate brokerages for new agents match you with someone who actually has time to answer questions, offer feedback, and walk you through awkward scenarios (like what to say when your buyer suddenly wants to “think about it” mid-escrow).

Ask if the mentorship is structured – how often you meet, what’s covered, and how mentors are selected. Vague “you’ll have support” promises are a red flag. You need someone who can spot your blind spots and help you build your skills, not just collect a fee on your closings.

3. Supportive Company Culture

New agents fail most often because they feel isolated and overwhelmed. That’s where company culture comes in.

A supportive brokerage means open-door managers, collaborative agents, tech help that actually shows up, and a place where asking questions isn’t treated like a weakness. Culture shows up in little things – who’s willing to share scripts, who answers your Slack messages, and whether there’s a community that makes you feel like you’re not doing this alone.

Before you join, talk to other agents. Ask what support really looks like. You’ll feel the vibe pretty quickly.

4. Tech That Works (And Helps)

Modern real estate runs on systems. Your brokerage should give you access to tools like a solid CRM, digital marketing tools, and listing tech that doesn’t look like it’s from 2005.

At minimum, look for:

  • CRM with follow-up automation (like Boldtrail or similar)
  • Email and text drips
  • Social media content tools
  • eSign and transaction management systems
  • Virtual office platforms for training and collaboration

Why? Because tech that works means less time in paperwork purgatory and more time closing deals – or, let’s be honest, generating leads to get there.

5. Lead Generation Support

Leads are the lifeline of a new agent’s business. The best real estate companies for new agents don’t just say “go find clients” – they help you do it (like Revenos at eXp).

That could mean PPC ads, relocation referrals, open house strategies, or sphere marketing tools. Some brokerages offer leads directly, others coach you on how to generate and convert them. The key is understanding what systems are in place – and what’s expected of you to make them work.

Ask: Are leads provided? Is there training on conversion? And do I pay extra for them?

6. Long-Term Growth Opportunities

Yes, it’s about closing your first deal – but it’s also about what happens after deal #10. The best real estate brokerage firms for beginners also help you plan your next chapter.

That might mean:

  • Coaching to scale into a team leader role
  • Management tracks or specialist positions
  • Continued education (marketing, negotiation, compliance)
  • Conferences, masterminds, and skill-building events

If your brokerage only focuses on the next deal, they’re not planning for your future. Ask about growth paths before you join.

Choose the Brokerage That Sets You Up to Win

There’s no one-size-fits-all answer to the best real estate brokerage for new agents – but there is one universal truth: support matters more than hype. You need a brokerage that actually trains you, supports you when you’re stuck, and helps you grow beyond just your first deal. We’ve got way more info to help you compare what different brokerages actually offer and most of it is nearly impossible to find through basic online searches.

Speaking of brokerages…

When you choose Smart Agent Alliance as your sponsor at eXp Realty, you don’t just get the most agent-forward brokerage in the game. You get double the firepower – Smart Agent Alliance + the Wolf Pack. We’re two of the most respected teams at eXp, and we’ve built our systems to help new agents actually succeed.

Here’s what you get free when you name a Smart Agent Alliance founder as your sponsor:

  • A custom agent attraction site, 8 landing pages, and automated email follow-up
  • Plug-and-play marketing templates and a top-ranked team website
  • Weekly coaching calls, agent production plans, and private referral groups
  • Social Agent Academy Pro (a $10.5K value)
  • And so much more!

You could choose a random eXp sponsor and hope for the best. Or you could join a team that has already built the engine, so all you have to do is drive.

Explore our team or join eXp with us at SmartAgentAlliance.com

Frequently Asked Questions

What is the best real estate brokerage for new agents?

The best brokerage for new agents is one with strong training, mentorship, tech, and support.

Is eXp Realty good for new agents?

Yes, eXp Realty offers daily training, sponsor team support, and powerful virtual tools for new agents.

Should new agents join a team?

Joining a team can speed up learning and provide leads, but it also reduces your commission split.

What is a sponsor at eXp Realty?

A sponsor is the person you name when joining eXp – ideally a team of agents who offers tools, coaching, and support.

What fees should new agents watch out for?

Watch for marketing fees, franchise fees, desk fees, and per-transaction charges – they can quickly add up.

Do all brokerages offer training for new agents?

No. Some offer great training, others offer none. Always ask to see the training calendar before joining.

Can I switch my eXp sponsor if I made a mistake?

Not directly. You’d need to leave the company for a full year and rejoin to change sponsors. But eXp’s new co-sponsor opportunity can help you correct your mistake without leaving.

What’s the difference between a production team and a sponsor team?

Production teams often provide leads and take a commission split (on top of your brokerages). Sponsor teams offer systems and support, usually without taking your commission.

title: Crush Real Estate Agent Tasks with the Right Planner
excerpt: Key Points Real estate agent tasks build up fast without the right planning system A strong real estate agent planner keeps follow-ups, listings, and priorities…
content:
Key Points

  • Real estate agent tasks build up fast without the right planning system
  • A strong real estate agent planner keeps follow-ups, listings, and priorities on track
  • Real estate agent time management is critical to closing more deals
  • Use planners that sync with your CRM, email, and calendar
  • A good real estate agent daily planner helps block time and track goals
  • Teams need shared agent task management tools to avoid dropped balls
  • Digital planners offer flexibility, reminders, and automation
  • Paper planners help agents who think better with pen and paper
  • The best planner for real estate agents fits your workflow – not just your desk

Real estate agent tasks don’t politely line up – they stampede. Between showings, lead follow-ups, your real estate agent marketing plan, and that last-minute “just checking in” text from a client who ghosted you three weeks ago, it’s a miracle anything gets done. Heads up: “just winging it” is not a business strategy – it’s a fast track to burnout, missed deals, and crying in your car between appointments.

The best real estate planners (digital or paper) don’t just help you stay organized – they help you stay in business. Whether you’re a sticky-note junkie or living in your Google Calendar, this blog is your no-fluff guide to picking a planner that actually supports your real estate agent plan – not sabotages it.

Here’s your handy dandy index:

Table of Contents

Section 1: Why Real Estate Agents Need a Planner
Section 2: Real Estate Agent Task & Goal Management
Section 3: Planning as a Team Sport
Section 4: Digital vs. Paper Planners for Agents
Section 5: Comparing Real Estate Planners
Trello for Real Estate Agents
2025 Real Estate Agent Planner Pro
PhoneLife Daily Realtor Digital Planner
Vertical Week + Month Planner
Gemma Weekly Weekly/Monthly Planning Calendar
ClickUp for Real Estate Agents
Monday.com for Real Estate Teams
Basecamp for Real Estate Collaboration
Smartsheet for Real Estate Project Tracking
Flowlu for Comprehensive Real Estate Management
Asana for Real Estate Agents
The Planner Is the Playbook: Stop Winging It, Start Winning It
Frequently Asked Questions

Section 1: Why Real Estate Agents Need a Planner

Your Real Estate Agent Plan Starts Here

Real estate agent tasks don’t trickle in – they flood your day like buyers at a price drop. Showings, offers, lead follow-ups, and that never-ending real estate agent marketing plan? Yeah, that’s all before noon. Without a real estate agent planner – ideally a modern real estate agent daily planner 2025 style system – you’re one missed appointment away from chaos.

Top producers aren’t winging it. Ask them what real estate agents do and you won’t hear “panic-scroll through texts to remember who they forgot.” A solid real estate agent plan doesn’t just keep your calendar clean – it keeps your sanity intact. The best planner for real estate agents doesn’t live in a junk drawer. It’s built around real estate agent best practices, designed to keep up with your listings, leads, and all the fire drills in between.

Why Time Management Is Where Agents Crash and Burn

This job doesn’t come with a manual – but it should come with a planner. The top mistake? Thinking you’ll “just remember.” And then you don’t. One missed call, one forgotten contract, and poof – there goes the deal. Real estate agent time management isn’t optional; it’s the entire ball game.

Wondering what software do real estate agents use to stay on track? The smart ones use a synced, automated, task-eating real estate agent planner that talks to their CRM, email, and calendar. Because consistency closes, and Post-it notes do not.

Section 2: Real Estate Agent Task & Goal Management

Mastering the Real Estate Agent To-Do List

Let’s not pretend: real estate agent daily tasks aren’t complicated, they’re just relentless. You’re juggling prospecting, nurturing, contracts, your real estate agent marketing plan, and maybe eating a snack if there’s time. The trick isn’t doing more – it’s doing what matters.

A proper agent task management setup helps you filter the noise. Forget “productivity hacks.” You need a real estate agent daily planner that helps you stick to your agent to-do list and block time for actual money-making activities. Preferably one that doesn’t get buried under a pile of listing flyers.

Track Progress Like You Mean It

A smart real estate agent planner 2025 doesn’t just collect tasks – it shows you progress. Whether it’s 20 calls, 3 meetings, or 2 deals this month, you should know exactly where you stand. The right system turns tasks into wins and inertia into closings.

Time Block Like Your Commission Depends on It (Because It Does)

Forgetting a task isn’t a whoops – it’s a lost paycheck. Great real estate agent time management means using reminders, recurring tasks, and blocking time for things like lead gen and offer follow-ups. Set it. Stick to it. Stop trying to run your business off memory alone.

Section 3: Planning as a Team Sport

Your Agent Planner Isn’t Just for You

Tasks of a real estate agent expand in direct proportion to the number of people on your team. Suddenly it’s not just your chaos – it’s a shared group project with commission checks on the line. That’s why your real estate agent planner needs to double as a team command center.

Shared visibility = fewer “Wait, who was doing that?” moments. A synced agent calendar or agent task management tool keeps everyone on the same page, so no one’s dropping the ball – or the open house signs.

Section 4: Digital vs. Paper Planners for Agents

Digital Planners: Built for Speed and Sanity

Ask any efficient agent what real estate agent tools are worth it, and they’ll point to their digital planner. The best real estate planners in 2025 do more than schedule – they sync your calendar, leads, tasks, and even your follow-ups. You want real real estate agent time management? Start blocking time for calls, showings, and those “quick” emails that hijack your day.

Most digital planners sync with your CRM, email, and tools like Calendly or Google Calendar. It’s like putting your real estate agent tasks on cruise control – minus the crashes.

Paper Planners: For Agents Who Think in Ink

If you’re the type who remembers things better after physically writing them, a paper real estate agent planner still does the job. It’s tactile, distraction-free, and lets you focus without falling into the TikTok time warp. Some agents even double-dip – digital for schedule, paper for strategy.

Just remember: no matter the format, a real estate agent plan only works if you actually use it. Your fancy leather planner doesn’t matter if it lives in your trunk.

Section 5: Comparing Real Estate Planners

Let’s get to the information you’ve been waiting for, the very best planners out there.

Trello for Real Estate Agents

Best for: Visual thinkers who prefer a drag-and-drop board layout

Features Agents Love:

  • Kanban-style boards with cards for listings, clients, or marketing campaigns
  • Checklists inside each card (perfect for deal stages)
  • Power-ups like calendar views and CRM syncing
  • The mobile app is smooth and easy to use on the go

How Agents Use It:

  • Use one board per pipeline (buyers, sellers, under contract)
  • Track lead status: Cold ? Warm ? Active ? Under Contract ? Closed
  • Organize real estate agent marketing plans with scheduled social posts and content links

Bonus:

Trello is fantastic for solo agents or those building out a real estate agent plan visually with flexibility and less setup than Asana.

2025 Real Estate Agent Planner Pro

Best for: Solo agents who want a sleek, fillable daily planning system without carrying a physical notebook

Features Agents Love:

  • Daily layout with time-blocking, lead tracking, and follow-up prompts
  • Sections for affirmations, gratitude, goals, and prospecting
  • Monthly and quarterly goal review pages
  • Instantly downloadable and fillable on any tablet or PDF app

How Agents Use It:

  • Use on an iPad or tablet as a fully digital real estate agent daily planner
  • Fill it out each morning with top 3 goals, client priorities, and content tasks
  • Review performance and adjust strategy weekly

Bonus:

If you like structure but want flexibility, this planner’s format is perfect for staying organized without needing sticky notes.

PhoneLife Daily Realtor Digital Planner

Best for: Agents who want a vintage-inspired aesthetic digital planner.

Features Agents Love:

  • Elegant, antique design with realtistic coils
  • Digital tabs for daily, weekly, and monthly views
  • Space for lead info, marketing plans, call logs, and transaction timelines
  • PDF format – designed for GoodNotes, Notability, or similar

How Agents Use It:

  • Navigate between sections instantly on your tablet
  • Organize multiple clients and listing stages in a beautiful layout
  • Keep everything from goal tracking to time blocking in one app

Bonus:

A planner with style and strategy – it looks like a keepsake but works like a machine.

Vertical Week + Month Planner

Best for: Agents who love time-blocking and want to see their week and month in one view

Features Agents Love:

  • Full weekly and monthly layout shown side-by-side
  • Vertical time blocks perfect for showing hours and appointments
  • Ample space for personal and professional notes
  • Premium-quality paper and stylish hard cover

How Agents Use It:

  • Set appointments in vertical time blocks for showings and closings
  • Write weekly prospecting goals alongside daily tasks
  • Keep both your personal and business calendars aligned

Bonus:

Perfect for agents who hate flipping pages and want to see everything now.

Gemma Weekly Weekly/Monthly Planning Calendar

Best for: New agents or budget-conscious pros who need a no-fuss, full-size planner

Features Agents Love:

  • 8.5×11 size gives you tons of space to write
  • Clean, modern layout with monthly and weekly pages
  • Monthly tab dividers and a durable cover
  • Affordable and easy to replace annually

How Agents Use It:

  • Track appointments, tasks, and follow-ups without digital distractions
  • Use as a transaction and listing timeline calendar
  • Jot down client notes, lead status, and to-do lists

Bonus:

It’s the entry-level best planner for real estate agents who want structure without the price tag.

ClickUp for Real Estate Agents

Best for: Agents and teams desiring a customizable, all-in-one productivity platform.

Features Agents Appreciate:

  • Customizable dashboards for tracking listings, leads, and marketing campaigns.
  • Task automation, reminders, and recurring tasks to manage follow-ups and deadlines.
  • Integration capabilities with calendars, CRMs, and communication tools.
  • Time tracking and goal-setting features to monitor productivity.

How Agents Utilize It:

  • Organize tasks by client, property, or transaction stage.
  • Set up templates for recurring processes like new listings or buyer onboarding.
  • Collaborate with team members by assigning tasks and sharing updates in real-time.

Bonus:

ClickUp’s versatility allows agents to tailor the platform to their specific needs, making it a flexible choice for various real estate operations.

Monday.com for Real Estate Teams

Best for: Teams seeking a visual and collaborative approach to project management.

Features Agents Appreciate:

  • Visual boards to track property statuses, client interactions, and marketing efforts.
  • Automated notifications and reminders to stay on top of tasks.
  • Integration with tools like Gmail, Outlook, and various CRMs.
  • Time tracking and reporting features to assess team performance.

How Agents Utilize It:

  • Manage the entire sales pipeline from lead generation to closing.
  • Coordinate open houses, showings, and client meetings.
  • Monitor marketing campaigns and their effectiveness.

Bonus:

Monday.com’s intuitive interface makes it easy for teams to adopt and customize workflows without extensive training.

Basecamp for Real Estate Collaboration

Best for: Teams and brokerages focusing on communication and task management.

Features Agents Appreciate:

  • Centralized communication channels to reduce email clutter.
  • To-do lists, schedules, and document sharing in one platform.
  • Client access to specific projects for transparency.
  • Automatic check-ins to keep the team aligned.

How Agents Utilize It:

  • Coordinate with clients, photographers, and contractors during the listing process.
  • Share documents like contracts and disclosures securely.
  • Plan marketing strategies and track their implementation.

Bonus:

Basecamp’s simplicity and focus on communication make it a favorite for teams aiming to enhance collaboration without overwhelming complexity.

Smartsheet for Real Estate Project Tracking

Best for: Agents and teams requiring spreadsheet-like interfaces with advanced functionalities.

Features Agents Appreciate:

  • Grid, card, Gantt chart, and calendar views for versatile project tracking.
  • Automation of repetitive tasks and reminders.
  • Integration with tools like Google Workspace, Microsoft Office, and various CRMs.
  • Robust reporting and analytics features.

How Agents Utilize It:

  • Track transaction timelines and ensure compliance with deadlines.
  • Manage budgets for marketing and property preparations.
  • Analyze performance metrics to inform business decisions.

Bonus:

Smartsheet combines the familiarity of spreadsheets with powerful project management features, catering to agents who prefer data-driven approaches.

Flowlu for Comprehensive Real Estate Management

Best for: Agents seeking an all-in-one solution encompassing CRM, project management, and financial tracking.

Features Agents Appreciate:

  • Integrated CRM to manage client relationships and communication.
  • Project management tools to oversee transactions and marketing campaigns.
  • Financial modules for invoicing, expense tracking, and budgeting.
  • Knowledge base and document management for easy access to resources.

How Agents Utilize It:

  • Maintain detailed client profiles and track interactions.
  • Oversee the progress of listings from initiation to closing.
  • Manage financial aspects of the business, ensuring profitability.

Bonus:

Flowlu’s comprehensive suite of tools reduces the need for multiple platforms, streamlining operations for real estate professionals.

Asana for Real Estate Agents

Best for: Teams and agents who want automation, clarity, and structured workflows

Features Agents Love:

  • Task templates for transactions, listings, open houses, and follow-ups
  • Timeline views for closings and escrow periods
  • Recurring tasks (great for weekly marketing or lead follow-ups)
  • Integrations with Gmail, Slack, Google Calendar, Zapier, and CRMs like Follow Up Boss

How Agents Use It:

  • Create a “project” for each listing with subtasks for staging, photography, MLS upload, etc.
  • Assign tasks to transaction coordinators or team members
  • Set due dates and automate reminders

Bonus:

Asana has a “My Tasks” view that acts like a dynamic real estate agent daily planner. Agents can drag and drop tasks to prioritize each day.

The Planner Is the Playbook: Stop Winging It, Start Winning It

A chaotic day doesn’t mean you’re productive – it just means you’re reacting. With the right real estate agent planner, your tasks turn into deals, and your time finally works for you. Find more important agent career moves in our Agent Success Hub.

And, if you’re looking for some awesome ongoing agent support, check out Smart Agent Alliance. When you partner with Smart Agent Alliance at eXp Realty, you get the combined firepower of sponsors Smart Agent Alliance and the Wolf Pack – two of the most supportive and production-focused sponsor teams at eXp.

Here’s what you get with us:

  • A branded agent attraction site that works 24/7
  • Automated email drip campaigns to keep your name top-of-mind
  • Webinars and 1-on-1 support to help your prospects convert
  • Our high-converting website – ranked #2 in organic traffic across all eXp sponsor teams
  • Elite Wolf Pack training, weekly masterminds, and Mike Sherrard’s Social Agent Academy Pro

We even throw in done-for-you marketing templates, customizable landing pages, fast onboarding, and a centralized agent portal that ties it all together.

Choose the team that’s already built the engine – you just drive.
Learn more at SmartAgentAlliance.com

Frequently Asked Questions

What are the most important real estate agent tasks to track in a planner?

You should track appointments, follow-ups, open houses, social content, transaction timelines, and leads across every stage.

What software do real estate agents use to manage tasks and time?

Agents use tools like Follow Up Boss, Boldtrail, Trello, and Asana – often integrated into their real estate agent planner for daily task and calendar management.

Is a digital or paper planner better for real estate agents?

Digital planners are best for on-the-go automation and syncing. Paper planners work well for agents who prefer writing things down. Use what you’ll stick with.

Why is a real estate agent planner important for teams?

It keeps everyone aligned on responsibilities, timelines, and updates – avoiding miscommunications and dropped leads.

How does a real estate agent planner help with time management?

Planners let you block time for high-priority tasks, set reminders, and keep your day structured – so nothing important gets forgotten.

title: How eXp Onboarding Works in 6 Steps - And How Not to Blow It
excerpt: Key Points Your sponsor choice locks in your entire upline - choose wisely. The Join eXp application has no do-overs - list your sponsor carefully.…
content:
Key Points

  • Your sponsor choice locks in your entire upline – choose wisely.
  • The Join eXp application has no do-overs – list your sponsor carefully.
  • License transfer usually takes 2 – 4 days after eXp approval.
  • Great sponsors offer training, tech, and revenue share support.
  • Co-sponsors can’t provide team value, only individual support.
  • eXp onboarding spans 8 days, 1 – 5 hours of tasks per day.
  • Smart Agent Alliance helps simplify onboarding with 1-on-1 guidance.

Getting your real estate license was the hard part… said no one ever who’s been through onboarding alone at 2 a.m. with six tabs open, a sad snack, and zero clue what an ICA is (learn more about the Independent Contractor Agreement at eXp).

If you’re joining eXp Realty and wondering what fresh hell you’re walking into – or better yet, how to actually get set up for success – breathe. It’s not that bad… unless you don’t pick the right sponsor. (FYI: most eXp sponsors don’t offer anything besides a prayer.)

The eXp onboarding process is built for agents who are ready to hit the ground running at a top-tier virtual real estate brokerage. But like most things in real estate, how you start matters.

Table of Contents

What to Expect with eXp Realty Onboarding
Step 1: Pick a Sponsor (Carefully. Seriously.)
Step 2: Fill Out the Join eXp Application
Step 3: Wait for Active Status
Step 4: Receive Sponsor Value
Step 5: Optional Co-Sponsor
Step 6: eXp’s Onboarding Day 1 to Day 8 Tasks
Day 1: Welcome, Setup, and Must-Do Tasks
Day 2: Explore, Set Up Marketing Basics
Day 3: Skip and Chill
Day 4: Tools, Offices, and Extras
Day 5: Optional Revenue Tools (and Warnings)
Day 6: Skim & Save for Later
Day 7: Website, Branding, and Social
Day 8: Survey & Send-Off
Ready to Make Your Onboarding Count?
Smart Agent Alliance: The Sponsor Team That Works for Your Revenue Share
The Wolf Pack: Elite Training, Culture, and Collaboration
Even More with Smart Agent Alliance…
Frequently Asked Questions

What to Expect with eXp Realty Onboarding

eXp onboarding is built like a factory line – but in a good way. Fast, clean, and surprisingly functional. It’s designed to help eXp agents get fully equipped with the tools, training, and support needed to start buying and selling homes fast (translation: get paid sooner).

But if you walk in blind without knowing how it works? You could be in for a world of confusion – and maybe even regret.

So let’s break it down. Here’s a recap of the 6 key eXp Realty onboarding steps we’ll cover in detail below:

  1. Pick a Sponsor
  2. Fill out the Join eXp Application
  3. Wait for Active Status
  4. Receive Sponsor Value
  5. Optional Co-Sponsor
  6. eXp’s Official 8 Day Onboarding Kicks Off

Step 1: Pick a Sponsor (Carefully. Seriously.)

If we sound like a broken record here, good. Because picking your eXp sponsor is the most important decision you’ll make outside of “should I become a real estate agent in the first place?”

Here’s why: most eXp Realty agents never realize how much sponsor support varies until it’s too late – and then they have agent sponsor regrets. Most eXp sponsors offer nothing. Others, like Smart Agent Alliance, offer an entire ecosystem of tools, mentorship, training, marketing help, and production support. We’re talking real support – not “give me a call if you need something.”

Pro tip: This sponsor choice includes the sponsor you name and their full upline of 6 more agents.  So, don’t blow this. Choose a sponsor who’s part of a strong upline team. Lone-wolf agents can’t give you the kind of leverage that team sponsors with layers of support (like us) can. It’s the difference between plugging into a system… or being left Googling “how to get started as a real estate agent” at 1 a.m.

Quick heads-up on common confusion:
Your eXp sponsor is not the same as a production team leader or mentor. Some agents make this confusing on purpose (shocker), especially if they’ve built a fancy site around their local production team.

Here’s the breakdown:

  • Sponsor teams – You must name them when you apply to eXp. They offer various levels of agent support (ranging from “literally nothing” to “why didn’t I join this sooner?”). They cost you $0.
  • Production teams – You join them anytime after you’re an active eXp agent. They’re great for day-to-day transaction help – but they take 25%+ of your commission.

Step 2: Fill Out the Join eXp Application

Once you’ve picked your sponsor (hi, hopefully us), you’ll go to the Join eXp application. Here’s what happens next:

  1. First, if you have any trouble with your application, reach out to eXpert Care at 833-303-0610 or contact your sponsor.
  2. Access the official Join Us platform through eXp’s website.
  3. Fill it out completely. Double-check that your name matches your real estate license exactly.
  4. Name your sponsor (don’t skip this – if you leave it blank, you don’t get a do-over.)
  5. Set up direct deposit and upload your W-9
  6. Read and sign your Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) – this defines your business relationship with eXp Realty. Not exactly beach reading, but it matters.
  7. Submit – your application is reviewed by eXp Onboarding (usually within 24 hours)

Step 3: Wait for Active Status

Once your app is approved by eXp Onboarding, it gets passed to your state broker, who pulls your license from your old brokerage or your state department of real estate if you’re brand new.

That process usually takes 48 – 72 hours, depending on your state.

In the meantime, don’t just refresh your inbox 37 times a day. Instead:

  • Ask your sponsor for an eXp World pass – take a tour, click around
  • Get your professional photos done – you’ll need them for your marketing
  • Haven’t heard anything from eXp in 4 days? Call eXpert Care (833-303-0610) and ask to speak to onboarding.

Step 4: Receive Sponsor Value

Congrats – you’re now an active eXp Realty agent. This is where it gets real.
If you chose a sponsor who actually delivers (like Smart Agent Alliance), this is when the good stuff kicks in – and it’s all free:

  1. Private 1-on-1 onboarding call
  2. Production help with top courses and live tips
  3. Revenue share support for passive income
  4. Community, connection, motivation, inspiration
  5. Access to training, tools, and templates

But if your sponsor ghosted you… or you didn’t realize that naming a sponsor on your application locked in your access to a full upline team and not just one person, yeah – it stings.

The good news? You’re not completely out of luck. You still have one more card to play: the co-sponsor.

Step 5: Optional Co-Sponsor

You’ve got 5 days from the date you become active to name a co-sponsor if you’d like one.

This is a second layer of support – totally optional, but potentially helpful if you want to add a local connection or specific skillset to your corner. Think of it as filling in the gaps your primary sponsor team doesn’t meet.

Keep in mind: a co-sponsor can only offer individual support – not the full upline structure that comes with the primary sponsor you named on your eXp application. But if you choose wisely, the right co-sponsor can still bring meaningful value, mentorship, and strategic help to your business.

Need help finding one? Use the eXp directory to search by location and find someone whose vibe actually fits. Then call them. Ask what they’re willing to offer you – for free. Because handing over part of your revenue to someone who’s not lifting a finger? That’s how you build regret, not a career.

Step 6: eXp’s Onboarding Day 1 to Day 8 Tasks

Now that you’re officially in, it’s time to tackle the actual eXp onboarding process – the part where you stop asking “Where do I click?” and start saying, “Let’s close something.”

This is where the eXp Realty/Residential Quick Start Guide comes in. It’s a clear, step-by-step plan broken into eight manageable days of onboarding. Time commitment? Usually 1–5 hours per day. So, not a hostage situation – but still, put coffee on.

Here’s what you can expect from the onboarding process:

  • A clearly structured task list that builds on itself
  • eXpert Care concierge backup for things you just don’t get
  • And if you picked the right sponsor (ahem, Smart Agent Alliance), we’ll provide tips for effectively onboarding too, privately 1-on-1.

Ok, here’s what the official eXp onboarding really involves – minus the fluff and plus the hacks that make it faster.

Day 1: Welcome, Setup, and Must-Do Tasks

On Day 1, you can expect to:

  • Get to Know the Mentor Program (if applicable) – If you’re assigned one, you’ll circle back to this later. Pro tip: You can change your mentor if they’re not helpful.
  • Attend the Live Agent Startup Session – This will walk you through much of Day 1, so reserve your session first and make that your Day 1.
  • Join Your Local Realtor Association, State Association, and MLS – This isn’t optional. It’s the cost of being a “Realtor” and a local member with the ability to do an agent’s job. 
  • Attend Your State Broker Orientation – Meet your broker, learn the ropes.

You’ll also knock out some quick tech setup on Day 1. Start by finding your eXp email alias through OKTA – this acts as your “passport” to all things eXp. Then log in to Workplace and Workplace Chat (just poke around – you don’t need to master it today), as well as My eXp and Enterprise, two key platforms you’ll get familiar with over time. You’ll also want to opt in to kvCORE (now called BoldTrail) to trigger the creation of your agent website – just note it takes about 7–10 days to go live. And spend a few minutes learning about SkySlope, our transaction management platform, but save the training for when you have a transaction.

Day 2: Explore, Set Up Marketing Basics

On Day 2, it’s time to:

  • Set Up Your Voicemail – Yes, people still leave voicemails.
  • Tour eXp World – If you can squeeze in the 30-minute tour today, do it.
  • Decide on Your Business Phone – Use your cell, Google Voice, or pay monthly for Twilio. (We use our cells.)
  • Order Marketing Materials – The free starter kit is from BuildASign, but what’s included changes. If you want to use a custom design, no problem.  Just get broker approval.
  • Explore Exclusive eXp Canva Marketing Templates
  • Set Up Your Email Alias & Signature – Only needed if you want to reply from your @exprealty.com email via Gmail or Yahoo.

Day 3: Skip and Chill

Day 3 is basically your breather day. eXp’s task list includes checking out the eXp Training Calendar and poking around eXp University – but honestly, if you’re with a strong training team like Smart Agent Alliance, you’ll probably get more value from our live coaching and production systems than sifting through generic modules. Translation: don’t waste hours here on Day 3.

This is also the day when new agents (fewer than 3 closed deals in the last 12 months) get introduced to the Mentor Program. If that’s you, block out a full hour to understand how it works and what to expect moving forward – it’s worth the time. But never forget – you can change your mentor if you don’t vibe with the assigned eXp Certified Mentor.

Day 4: Tools, Offices, and Extras

Here’s what you can expect for Day 4, you’ll visit:

  • DISC Assessment via Success Coaching – 10 minutes of personality quiz fun. Optional.
  • Clearwater Agent Healthcare – Only if you need it.
  • Regus Office Access – Free shared office lounges if you want a professional space to work or meet clients.
  • SISU – Analytics and tracking tool. Note it for later.
  • eXp DialSafe – Only relevant if you’re cold calling.

Day 5: Optional Revenue Tools (and Warnings)

Ok, Day 5 includes a lot of information that new agents don’t need right away.  So, skip most of this section unless you’re ready to explore:

  • Zenlist – Off-market listings and an upgraded MLS-style interface.
  • Revenos – eXp-provided leads (eXp Relocation, Affinity, Military, BundleSelect, REO, Institutional Investment Services) but you’ll pay 25%–55% when deals close. Get certified to access. Pro tip: Certify faster at eXpCON – 3 hours vs. 12.
  • Express Offers – Great for new agents. Learn how to submit investor offers quickly.
  • Making It Rain – made for you Facebook Ads, explore when ready.

Day 6: Skim & Save for Later

Day 6 is another light day – think of it as a choose-your-own-adventure, but without the pressure to actually choose anything yet. This is your chance to scroll through some of the optional tools and programs eXp offers. Just read the explanations, get a feel for what’s available, and file them away in your brain (or bookmarks) for when the time is right.

You’ll come across things like eXp Solutions, the paid Lofty CRM (for those who don’t vibe with BoldTrail), and extras like eXp Stock Programs, Success Lending, Flowcode, and even the Luxury Certification. It’s all good stuff – but none of it needs action today. Skim now, explore later.

Day 7: Website, Branding, and Social

Today’s all about polishing your online presence – but only if the timing makes sense. If your BoldTrail site (formerly kvCORE) is live, now’s the time to jump in and start customizing it. If not, no stress – just make a note to come back when it is.

You’ll also see a prompt to start promoting yourself on social media. If that’s already your thing, go for it. If not? Hold off and check out our free training instead – it’s designed for agents who don’t want to learn the hard way.

You’ll also get nudged to “expand your network” and “review eXp docs,” but honestly, those are just friendly suggestions. If you’re in the mood to connect, great. If not, save it for another day. There’s no prize for reading every document twice.

Day 8: Survey & Send-Off

You made it to the final day – nicely done. The only task on your plate is the NPS survey. It goes directly to eXp (not us), but yes, they really do care about your feedback. So be honest, but maybe don’t unload about your cousin’s expired license drama.

Once that’s done? You’re officially onboarded. Welcome to eXp Realty. Time to shift from setup mode to success mode – and don’t worry, we’ll be right here to help you make it count.

Ready to Make Your Onboarding Count?

The eXp onboarding process is fast, structured, and – if you know what to expect – not nearly as overwhelming as it looks from the outside. Whether you’re just figuring out how to get started as a real estate agent or you’re a seasoned pro switching to a virtual real estate brokerage, one thing holds true: your first few days set the tone for everything else.

From sponsor selection to tech setup to navigating the official onboarding process, it’s easy to miss crucial support if you don’t know what you’re doing – or who you’re working with. Don’t let a weak sponsor stall your momentum. This is your business, and you deserve better than ghosted emails and outdated checklists.

That’s Where We Come In.

When you choose Smart Agent Alliance as your sponsor, you get the combined firepower of Smart Agent Alliance and the Wolf Pack – two of the most value-packed, support-driven groups in all of eXp Realty. Together, we’ve got you covered on everything agents actually care about: community, production support, and passive income growth through revenue share.

Smart Agent Alliance: The Sponsor Team That Works for Your Revenue Share

Let’s be honest – most agents don’t join eXp thinking about revenue share. But ask a long-time eXp agent their #1 regret? Not building it sooner. At Smart Agent Alliance, we actually invest time and money into helping you grow passive income through the revenue share model. Here’s what you get:

  • A branded agent attraction webpage to recruit passively
  • High-converting email drip campaigns and webinars
  • 1-on-1 calls to close interested agents for you
  • Access to the #2 highest traffic agent site among all eXp sponsor teams

So yeah – it’s like free money, but with a system that actually works.

The Wolf Pack: Elite Training, Culture, and Collaboration

As part of the Wolf Pack, you also get:

  • Two team-wide strategy calls per week, plus an exclusive women’s mastermind
  • Mike Sherrard’s Social Agent Academy Pro (a $10,500 system sold at $997/year – yours for free)
  • Courses on flipping, production, CRM mastery, and more
  • Private access to team WhatsApp chats and Skool communities for fast answers and agent referrals

Even More with Smart Agent Alliance…

We also hook you up with:

  • 8 customizable landing pages
  • Done-for-you marketing templates
  • Quick-start plans, personal onboarding, and an all-in-one agent portal
  • Support that feels like someone actually cares – because we do

You could roll the dice with a random sponsor… or you could plug into a system that’s already working. Your onboarding is just the beginning – but the right sponsor makes it your launching pad.

To learn more about eXp Realty – the only publicly traded real estate brokerage that’s been profitable for the last five years and voted the #1 brokerage to work for – or to see how Smart Agent Alliance can help you scale faster, smarter, and with more freedom:

Your move, agent.

Frequently Asked Questions

How does eXp Realty onboarding work?

eXp Realty onboarding starts after you apply and name your sponsor. Once approved and your license is transferred, you’ll follow an 8-day Quick Start Guide that walks you through tools, training, and systems.

What do I need before onboarding with eXp?

Before onboarding, you need to pick a sponsor, complete the Join eXp application, and be ready to pay your $85 monthly and $64 first-month admin fee. New agents also must pay their Realtor association and MLS fees to those entities (not to eXp).

Can I change my sponsor after joining eXp Realty?

No. Once your application is submitted, you cannot change your sponsor (includes their upline value). However, you have 5 days after activation to name an optional individual co-sponsor (does not include their upline value.)

How long does it take to become active at eXp Realty?

After submitting your application, most agents are active within 1–4 days, depending on how quickly your state broker transfers your license.

What is the mentor program at eXp Realty?

Agents with fewer than 3 closed deals in the past 12 months are automatically assigned an eXp Certified Mentor. The split is 60/40 for your first 3 deals, then you go to the normal 80/20 split. You can switch mentors if the assigned one isn’t a fit.
